div.head: Section 18
div.p: ¶ Fourthly it is proved that without the free consent and approval of those peoples and their kings themselves, another new king cannot be given to them or established over their natural kings, thus.

¶ We can allege the authorities and examples of sacred scripture for the decision of causes and determination of doubts, as is the text in c. per venerabilem extra qui fil sint legitimi: and what is noted there and in c. 2 de prescriptionibus and in c. cum apostolus de censibus and de prebendis c. cum secundum

This is also proved by two glosses of civil law.
One in authent. Ut iudices: sine quoquo suffragio § cogitatio in verbo eloquiorum . The other in l. illud ff. ad l. aquiliam Baldus in authent. ad hec 2 columna C. de usuris The same Baldus alleges the Apostle in rubrica C. de fide instrumentorum. And the jurists say this is true unless there were a law contrary to divine authority, because then one would stand by the law.

This is however limited: unless divine authority were speaking concerning things pertaining to the soul, because then it is superior not only to civil law § finali de secundis nuptiis: but also to canon law or to the hearer of canon: 25, q. 1. c. sunt quidam concerning this see Felinus in c. ex parte el 1o 20 columna de scriptis.

¶ But in sacred scripture it is found ordained: in order that in the giving or establishment of a new and supreme prince from the beginning, even concerning a prince whom God had designated or chosen, there should intervene the free consent and authority and voluntary acceptance of the peoples: without which even divine institution concerning the supreme prince did not obtain effect.
Therefore without the free consent and approval of those peoples and their kings themselves, a new King cannot be given to them or established.

We say notably from the beginning, namely before the kingdom or principate is transferred by succession. Since from the beginning every principate or governance of a people has drawn its origin from the consent and election of the people l. ex hoc iure ff. de iustitia et iure and
ff.
de origine iuris l. 2 § deinde cum essent
and § nouissime and ff. de constitutione principum l. 2 and
instit. de iure naturali gentium et ciuili § sed et hoc studiosum
and in
authent. de instrumentorum cautela et fide § et quia imperium

The consequence is evident. The Minor is proved by that passage in Deuteronomy 17 where it is said thus:
When you shall enter the land which the Lord your God will give you and shall possess it and shall dwell in it, and shall say: I will set a king over me, as all nations have round about, you shall set him whom the Lord your God shall choose from among the number of your brethren
etc.
¶ In which words indeed the Lord decreed that two things ought to concur for the institution of a king and the exercise of royal power.

One from the part of the one instituting, namely that he should have been elected by divine providence, awaiting in the election the judgment of God. The other from the part of the people: namely that the people should voluntarily receive such a one elected by God as king and willingly hold it as valid and hand over possession of the kingdom. Which two things the aforesaid words clearly denote, namely "you shall set him whom the Lord your God shall choose" where a voluntary act, that is the consent and approval of the people, was required. There "you shall set him" that is you will hold as valid or will accept and will have as king over you him whom God will have indicated to you as having been chosen: or as having been pleasing to him to be king.

Whence although God could have established a king over the Hebrew people even unwilling: both because he is the Lord of all according to Hebrews, and any man and any people is a servant of God by nature: and more than a servant, namely like inanimate property to its possessor, and thus he could do with his property whatever he wished, and especially because with him are the dominions and rights of the kingdoms of the earth: and he can give them to whom he wills, as appears in Daniel 4:
Until you know that the Most High rules in the kingdom of men and will give it to whom he will
Especially because that people was governed under the special care of God, as appears in Deuteronomy 7
The Lord your God has chosen you to be his peculiar people
and Exodus 19:
You shall be to me a peculiar possession from among all peoples . Nevertheless he did not wish to deprive them of the privilege of natural law by which it pertains to every man and to every free people to submit themselves of their own accord to another's governance if they see it useful to them. For God does not destroy or abrogate his work or natural law which from the beginning he himself so wisely, so ordinately, as if immutably, instituted.

For it does not belong to divine
providence to compel or corrupt natures, as the great Dionysius in D 4 de diuinis nominibus says: Whence just as by divine ordinance it had the force of a precept that the people should voluntarily set over themselves as king the one whom the Lord chose, that is they should hold such an election of God as valid and hand over to him possession of the kingdom: so equally by divine ordinance the consent and ratification of the people and the handing over of possession of the kingdom were necessarily required for the exercise of royal power. Which consent of the people and acceptance and handing over of possession of the kingdom, if God did not require: he would certainly have said only:
He shall be king over you whom the Lord your God shall choose . Nor would it be necessary to say you shall set him whom the Lord etc. Because however he said you shall set him: he clearly indicates that by divine ordinance it is also necessarily required from the part of the people: some act, namely consent and ratification or voluntary acceptance: and also the handing over of possession must truly intervene. For the words of sacred scripture must be weighed since they are full of mysteries: and to think that anything improper, superfluous or diminished can be found in it would be impious.

¶ This is most evident in the establishment of the first two kings, namely Saul and David. For as is found in I Kings c. 10 although Saul had previously been anointed as King by Samuel at God's command and through that anointing had acquired the right and title to that kingdom: nevertheless afterward it was necessary that he be instituted and accepted by the people as king and that possession of the kingdom be handed over to him. Nor did Saul dare to exercise the jurisdiction or authority of royal power, nor could he by full right, until the people should consent to the election made concerning him and should hand over or grant to him possession of the kingdom.

For thus it is read at the beginning of that tenth chapter: And Samuel took a flask of oil and poured it upon Saul's head and kissed him and said: Behold the Lord has anointed you over his inheritance as prince. Then indeed after some days had passed: Samuel called the people together to the Lord at Mizpah: and made them stand by tribes and families, and lots were cast first to determine the tribe, then the family, down to the men, and the lot came to Saul (when he was brought forth, because he had been hidden), the Lord said. Samuel said to all the people:
Surely you see whom the Lord has chosen: for there is none like him among all the people : and all the people cried out and said: Long live the King etc.
Behold the consent, ratification or acceptance of the people.

¶ After these things and not before, Saul began
to use royal power when having cut an ox in pieces, he sent it into all the territories of Israel by the hand of messengers saying.
Whoever shall not come out and follow Saul and Samuel
etc. cap. 10. And because some of the people had not willingly consented to God's election of Saul, although the title to reign had been conferred through anointing and again he had been voluntarily elected as King by lot and by God's command: but rather many were saying Can this one save us? Therefore to induce the people to consent Samuel said again to all the people:
Come let us go to Gilgal and renew the kingdom there . And all the people went to Gilgal: and they made Saul king there before the Lord in Gilgal etc.

Where it appears how much care and solicitude was applied by the will of God so that the privilege of natural liberty, namely of consenting voluntarily to a prince, should be preserved to the people, nor did he compel or reproach them: but he waited until they should voluntarily give consent to receiving the king and should hand over possession of the kingdom: although from the beginning he had been divinely chosen and the royal title conferred on him.

Therefore so that the king might have the exercise of royal power in that people and right in that kingdom: from divine ordinance divine institution concerning the king is not sufficient without the consent and acceptance of the people.
